g.text: Do Not Cite, Quote or Distribute
Other emerging work investigates the role of local
content requirements on innovation outcomes and
suggests that it can lead to increased power costs (negative distributional impacts) and the domestic
innovation system benefits, measured by patents or exports are unclear if the policies are not part of a
olistic and longer lasting policy framework
Intellectual property rights, legal framework and the impact on innovation
Virtually all countries around the world have instituted systems for the protection of creations an
inventions, known as Intellectual Property (IP) rights systems
patents, copyright, design rights, trademarks, and more
focus on patents, as the most relevant property right for technological innovations
, and hence the most relevant for policy instruments in thi
Patent systems aim to promote innovation and economic growth, by stimulating both the creation of
new knowledge and diffusion of that knowledge (
systems, as institutions, play a central role in th
Patent systems are usually instituted to promote innovation and economic growth
elson and Mazzoleni 1996; Machlup and Penrose 1950; Encaoua et al. 2006)
explicitly refer to this purpose in their law or legislation
for instance, the US Constitution states the
purpose of the US IP rights system to “promote the
progress of science and useful arts”.
aim to reach their goals by trying to strike a balance between the creation of new knowledge and
(Scotchmer and Green 1990; Devlin 2010; Anadon et al. 2016b)
promote the creation of new knowledge (e.g. technological inventions) by providing a temporary,
the holder of the patent, thus providing incentives to develop such new knowledge
and helping parties to justify investments in research and development. They promote the diffusion of
this new knowledge via the detailed disclosure of the invention in the p
enabling a ‘market for knowledge’ via the trading of patents and the issuance of licenses
. Although IP protections provide incentives to invest in innovation, they have the double effect
of restricting the use of new knowledge by raising
stems, as institutions, feature prominently in models
and theories of National Innovation Systems
The degree to which patent sys
tems actually promote innovation is subject to debate. Patent protection
has been found to have a positive impact on R&D activities in patent
was found to be conditional on access to finance
especially important to facilitate innovation in selected areas like pharmaceuticals, where investments
in developments and clinical trials are high,
imitation costs are low, and there is often a 1:1 relationship
between a patent and a product, referred to as a “discrete” product industry
same time, there is an increasing body of theoretical and empirical literature that suggest
proliferation of patents also discourages innovation (
contributions note that a too stringent appropriability regime may greatly limit the diffusion of advanced
block the development of differentiated technological
capabilities within an industry, in what is called an ‘appropriability trap’
standing debate on the impact of patents and other IP
rights on innovation and economic development
highlight how IP rights also hamper innovation in a variety
of ways. Other more specific contributions in the literature focus on specific factors. F
discusses patent thickets, where overlapping sets of patent rights mean that those
seeking to commercialize new technology, need to obtain licenses from multiple patentees. Heller and
argue that a ‘tragedy of the anticommons’ is likely to emerge when too many parties
obtain the right to exclude others from using fragmented and overlapping pieces of knowledge, with
